dialogues.text: (impressed) Light or dark? (Re: the chicken) Jane? Light meat or dark?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Er - light, please.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'll wing it. As usual. The old family PUNNING game has begun.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPA
dialogues.text: Boooo.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: How plucky of you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPA
dialogues.text: Ohh, fowl play! Fowl play.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Stop egging him on!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: It's so nicely cocked. Hawking laughter. Ha! Ha! JANE is bemused.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: (sympathetic, to JANE) Don't worry about them. They're pun mad. FRANK is about to place a slice of CHICKEN BREAST on JANE PLATE -—

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That's okay - (tentatively) - the breast is yet to come. FRANK guffaws, as he plates her chicken.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: HA! Marvelous! Very good. "The breast is yet to come!" Indeed it is! Well done. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 18

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Oh! - I'm inviting Jane to be my partner for the May Ball. It's news to JANE: shocked - but then pleased as he shoot her a quick look and mouths...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (silently mouthing) Will you? She SMILES and NODS, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by his PARENT's CAR, STEPHEN watches (SMITTEN) a - JANE, in a GORGEOUS GOWN, walks down the path toward hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the blaring strains of WAGNER, the HAWKING car careens across the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the GRAND FRONT LAWN of the COLLEGE, a fairy-tale part LIGHTS IN THE TREES, a throng of GOWNED YOUNG WOMEN, and YOUNG MEN IN BLACK TIE and TAILS, all sip CHAMPAGNE on th sequestered CROQUET LAWNS, as if from a by-gone age. A BATHTUB is full of CHAMPAGNE BOTTLES ON ICE. Through this STEPHEN and JANE drift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN and JANE stand and watch the swirling couples on dance-floor, sipping PUNCH. The MAY BALL is now in full and magical swing, as couples float across the lawns before the great facade of the college.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Should we dance, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no. Happy to observe the phenomenon--but I can't possibly imagine participating.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I absolutely agree. I mean, who would want to dance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 19

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No, I'm quite serious. I don't dance. JANE has a wistful look of disappointment. AWKWARD SILENC Just then - A BLUE UV LIGHT comes on. This causes great excitement on the dance-floor. All the other couples "ooh and "ahh" and even more people take to the floor - not so STEPHEN and JANE.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) Do you see how the men's cuffs and shirt-fronts, how they glow more than the dresses?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (smiles, expectant) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Do you know why?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The washing powder?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: The fluorescence in the washing powder is caught by the UV light.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (grins) When stars are born and when they die, they emit UV radiation. So if we could see the night sky in ultraviolet light, almost all the stars would disappear--and all we'd see would be these spectacular births and deaths. And I reckon-- it would look a little - JANE stares at the glowing swirling people with STEPHEN's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - like that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 20

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They watch, impressed, as - FIREWORKS are suddenly heard, EXPLODING LOUDLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) A FIRE-WORK DISPLAY - STEPHEN and JANE watch as SKY- ROCKETS light up the sky. B) A CAROUSEL - JANE and STEPHEN ride the CAROUSEL. STEPH watches JANE, captivated by her happiness in this moment. C) A CHAMPAGNE TENT - JANE selects a FLUTE OF CHAMPAGNE a takes a BIG SIP, to the sound of a NEARBY 1920's CHICAGO SWING band. The GATSBY-THEMED BAR-STAFF are dressed in 19 TUXEDOS and FLAPPER-DRESSES.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: So why... (passing champagne) ..-why...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Why medieval Spanish poetry? JANE surveys the gay party, sipping her champagne -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (happily) I suppose I like to time travel.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: And what particular time periods do you visit? JANE takes the CHAMPAGNE STEPHEN has just chosen and pour half of his into her glass.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The Twenties is always fun.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: The roaring twenties! Cheers! They CLINK GLASSES and sip their champagne, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So--The 1920's. A good time for poetry was it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 21

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: "Seek then/ No learning/ from Starry Men!/ Who follow with Optic Glass/ The Whirling Ways of Stars that Pass."

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Was it - They move off across the NEARBY DANCE-FLOOR, and PASS the JAZZ BAND en route to the LIGHTED FOOT-BRIDGE spanning a river under which LIGHTED PUNTS drift by.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - was it a good time for science?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: A smashing time actually. Spacetime was born.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Spacetime...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Space and Time finally got together. People always thought they were too dissimilar, couldn't possibly work out. But then along comes Einstein, the ultimate match- maker, and decided that space and time, not only had a future, but had been married all along.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The perfect couple! They arrive at the FOOT-BRIDGE, with its view of the BRID OF SIGHS. PUNTS with CATHERINE WHEELS are moored nearby. D) FOOT-BRIDGE. JANE and STEPHEN stop in the middle of the bridge. STEPHE looks up at the STARS, bright, sparkling. JANE does the s

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well that's astonishing, isn't it? Silence, then - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 22

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (seriously) "In the beginning was the heaven and the earth, and the earth was without form, and darkness-- darkness was upon the face of the deep." STEPHEN, moved, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Would you dance with me? He takes her hand and starts to DANCE with her to the mus and then tilts his head and KISSES her. CAMERA pulls back to reveal the couple kissing on the FOOTBRIDGE, the punts floating underneath, the night magi the lovely slow jazz drifting over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORNING LIGHT on the WILDE FRONT DOOR. JANE, in bathrobe, opens the door to get the MILK. Looks down. PAN down to - BOX of "TIDE" WASHING POWDER. She picks it up - looks aro for STEPHEN - smiles, delighted - IN LOVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCIAMA and STEPHEN and PHYSICISTS 1,2 and 3 arrive late o the platform. The train is already pulling in. SCIAMA, an the OTHER THREE all run for it. But STEPHEN is making his up the steps, not running - putting on a brave face. When STEPHEN arrives, just in time, the PHYSICISTS 1,2,3, pull STEPHEN on to the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they whistle along, English countryside in the backgro SCIAMA studies STEPHEN then returns his attention to his newspaper when he meets his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER PENROSE, MATHEMATICIAN, gives a passionate talk before a small audience in a small room. The blackboard i crammed with calculations and diagrams.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE
dialogues.text: So what do we know? Let me rephrase that--what do the equations tell us, finally? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 23

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns the blackboard over. A blank board.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about a simple diagram? Smiles, small laughter from the audience. STEPHEN looks especially relieved.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A star, more than three times the size of our sun... He draws a circle on the board.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .».-ought to end its life, how? With a collapse, the gravitational forces of the entire mass overcoming the electromagnetic forces of individual atoms, and so collapsing inwards. If the star is massive enough, it will continue this collapse, creating a black hole - where the warping of spacetime is so great that nothing can escape... not even light. It gets... He draws a smaller circle, inside the first.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smaller, smaller... An even smaller circle.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The star, in fact, gets denser as atoms--even subatomic particles-- get literally crushed, smashed into smaller and smaller space. And at its end point what are we left with? He draws a point. ROGER PENROSE (CONT’D) A point. A spacetime singularity... STEPHEN is captivated.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With extraordinary properties! Infinite density. Space and time come to a stop. All of the known laws of science--they just stop working. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 24

dialogues.speaker: ROGER PENROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What I've just shown is that this happens in every black hole. Its really happening, out there. To real stars--and its happening right now! STEPHEN smiles - seeing his future revealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCIAMA and his students, returning home. As his friends talk excitedly, STEPHEN is silently starin down at the CIRCULATING COFFEE in front of him, into whic he pours CREAM... SLOWLY, CLOCKWISE - the cream is spread outward by the circulating coffee until it looks like a SPIRAL GALAXY. As he stares, deep in thought, the SPIRAL of CREAM pulses with LIGHT - he is having an epiphany here - a major insight... ...and then TIME GOES INTO REVERSE. As it does so, the CR CHANGES DIRECTION, goes ANTI-CLOCKWISE now, the SPIRAL on more returning to its original central dollop, and then vanishing. The coffee creamless. STEPHEN looks up...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (to SCIAMA) I wonder what would happen--if--I wonder what would happen-- Sensing his protege is on to something, perhaps even a sm smile.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Go on. If?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: If you applied Penrose's theory about black holes to--the entire universe? SCIAMA stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN excitedly expands on his new idea to a DELIGHTED, SMILING JANE as they WALK side by side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 25

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: If--if--so--If--Einstein is right, if--general relativity is correct, then the universe is expanding, yes? —

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - Alright -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: - which means - that--if you reverse time, the universe would get smaller and smaller. So what if--if I reverse the process all the way to see what happened at the beginning of Time itself? The universe, smaller and smaller, denser and denser, hotter and hotter as we approach its birth. Wind back the clock... JANE grabs his hands and begins to SWIRL him around.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Winding back the clock!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Is that what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That's what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well keep winding! You've got quite a way to go. Keep winding, Jane! Keep winding...back to the beginning of Time...Keep winding... They SPIN faster and faster until they almost trip and on save themselves by clasping each other closely...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (suddenly serious) «.+-until you get -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN at the blackboard makes a DOT on the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: A singularity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 26

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: A spacetime singularity. At the beginning of time. SCIAMA stares at him. STEPHEN smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The universe born from a black hole exploding.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: (finally) Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Keep going? You mean go further back, Professor? Before the universe began?

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Keep going. Develop the mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I don't know how. SCIAMA takes the KEY for the RUTHERFORD LAB out of the dr and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN writes, inspired, formula on the famous blackboar He stops, thinks, continues, then deletes a bit, and writ again, faster, faster, his mind racing, even as his finge begin to betray him, growing weaker, weaker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swirl of CAMBRIDGE UNIVERSITY life. Dons on bicycles. Purposeful students. Every building looking like a STATEL HOME . STEPHEN walks quickly and excitedly, with still CHALKY FINGERS, across campus but then suddenly, trips - FALLS - falls hard. His head smashing onto the hard paving stones His GLASSES fly off his face. He is unconscious immediate STUDENTS rush to his aid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) X-RAY DEPARTMENT. STEPHEN, his face GRAZED and BRUISED lies on a tilting bed as X-rays are taken. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 27

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: B) Blood is taken from his arm. C) In a PUBLIC WARD, STEPHEN, sitting on the edge of a be in a HOSPITAL SMOCK, turns and looks at a SICK YOUNG MAN the next bed, who looks GRAVELY ILL. D) Dexterity Test - Stephen struggles to bring his little finger to meet his thumb. Stephen, lying down, as the doc violently jerks his knee up. Stephen lying prone in foeta postion as a doctor performs a lumbar puncture and extrac fluid from his spine.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What is it? What's wrong with me? E) STEPHEN lies in the PUBLIC WARD while the SICK YOUNG M in the next bed is discovered DEAD. Nurses rush the SICK YOUNG MAN away, as STEPHEN watches. He is very moved by t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR is dismissive and unsentimental.

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It's called motor neuron disease.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What's that? The DOCTOR, despite his unsentimental nature, draws a dee breath. This is not the speech he wants to make...

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It's a progressive neurological disorder that destroys the cells in the brain that control essential muscle activity such as speaking, walking--breathing-- swallowing. The signals that muscles must receive in order to move are disrupted, cut off. The result is--gradual muscle decay, a wasting away. Eventually, the ability to control voluntary movement is--lost--entirely. SHOCK sets in as STEPHEN watches other patients taking EXERCISE, stretching - walking.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Is--is--is there a cure? Some--? Is--can you--?

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Improvement should not be expected. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 28

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) I'm afraid average life expectancy is two years. STEPHEN is rocked to the core by this news - SENIOR DOCTOR (CONT’D) There's nothing I can do for you, I'm terribly sorry. Silence. The SENIOR DOCTOR rises to go -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Wait! What about--what about the brain?

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The brain isn't affected. Your thoughts won't change--it's just-

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SENIOR DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Eventually--no-one will know what they are. (beat) Ever so sorry. The DOCTOR walks away. REACTION: STEPHEN, devastated. Frozen. People walk past h and he doesn't move, doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WATER drips in SLOW MO from an old TAP. STEPHEN lies in a bath, in a TRANCE, knees drawn up, hair wet, not moving, in a STATE OF SHOCK, as he stares at the DRIPPING TAP, until - - his eyes are drawn to his ARM where he sees a weird PHENOMENON - it's called FASCICULATION - a visible throbb that travels underneath the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN rushes up the SPIRAL STAIRS, past the "BEDDER" - a woman who looks after the STUDENTS domestic needs.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (to BEDDER) Is he up yet?  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a pounding on his door, and then BRIAN enters STEPHEN's room. WAGNER is playing INCREDIBLY LOUDLY on an old TAPE-DECK. BRIAN shuts it off and looks at - - STEPHEN, in the corner, in his pyjamas, his MATRESS now the floor (rather than on the HIGH BUNK as before) legs d up, reading a book of CHESS.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: "Welcome--to this week's episode of The Natural World, where we explain the extraordinary hibernation patterns of the rare Cambridge Physicist--seen here in his wonderful plumage..." Silence. BRIAN waits for STEPHEN to speak.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So? What did they say? Your wrist. What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I have a disease, Bri.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (whispers) Is it--venereal, Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No. Motor neuron disease. Lou Gehrig's Disease. He was a baseball player.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Motor what? Sorry, I'm lagging behind in my pioneering work on rare automotive and baseball diseases. Come on, let's go to the pub. BRIAN tries to pull STEPHEN to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (impassively) I have two years to live. (Pause) Sounds strange, doesn't it, when you say it out loud.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: What? I--I don't understand. It's not possible! It's ridiculous! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 30

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were fine a couple of days ago. (silence) Steve? You're fine. What did they say...?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Will you leave me Brian?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, look, I was just being a berk...I'm so... The BEDDER knocks and enters.

dialogues.speaker: BEDDER
dialogues.text: Stephen! Phone for you! It's a girl. BRIAN has no choice. He is badly shaken by the news.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Right. OK. So--see you soon, yeah? STEPHEN does his best to smile. Brian exits.

dialogues.speaker: BEDDER
dialogues.text: (to STEPHEN) She's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE on phone.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stephen? Hi. It's me. (CLICK!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen? She holds the DEAD RECEIVER in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the swirl of UNIVERSITY life comes - JANE WILDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE knocks - gets no answer.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (knocks )

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, huddled against the door, refused to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks past the empty lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of undergraduates. JANE enters, looks around for STEPHEN. Can't see him. BRIAN, seated with the other YOUNG PHYSICISTS, spots her.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Jane! JANE comes up the young men.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Brian--have you seen Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Jane, have a seat. JANE sits.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I understand you saw him. You know he was in hospital... JANE nods, as the CAMERA pulls back from the scene, leavi BRIAN (sensitively) to pass the terrible news to JANE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks in, sees STEPHEN, slumped in an armchair watching TV in the common room. At a distance, JANE stops, shocked. He looks woebegone, depressed, physically reduced already. She summons up a cheerful demeanor, however, and advances.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Something educational?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (without looking at her) Very. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John is having an affair with Martha. But Martha is in love with Alan. And I think Alan is homosexual by the look of his shirts. I'm trying to work out the mathematical probability of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you close?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's some integer of zero, but I'm not there yet.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You just missed him. He was here earlier.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Cut me off.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Teach me croquet. (pause) Come on. Teach me. (pause) What is this?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I believe you poetry under- graduate types call it..."a slough of despond."

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If you don't get up and play a game with me I won't come back here again. Ever. Silence. He finally looks at her. ANGRILY he rises. And walks off ahead of her. She watches him. 32  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE AIMS, STRIKES, hits a FEEBLE SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: My turn. STEPHEN AIMS, HITS his BALL through the FIRST HOOP, then walks, as best he can, off toward his BALL, using his MAL as a WALKING STICK. With his second shot he hits her BALL then picks up his BALL, places it beside hers so that it touches, puts his foot on his ball, then smacks his BALL with his MALLET, blasting her ball down to the next hoop. He proceeds to play a MASTER GAME that will not allow JAN another shot, enlisting her ball to advance his own from to HOOP, until - - he knocks his ball and hits the finishing peg. JANE has been watching all this, her eyes FLOODING WITH TEARS, until she can bear it no longer, and walks up to h and picks up his ball, stopping the game. They stare into each others eyes, until he can bear it no longer and he w off (as best he can) back to his room. She watches him, then follows determinedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters ANGRILY, SLAMS the door behind him, then tries break a CHAIR by throwing it against the wall - just as J enters.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Go away. More knocks.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: STEPHEN? Let me in. Please. Please let me in.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Go away!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you going to talk about this or not? Silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 34

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: There's nothing to say-- just...(go)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: That's what I want. I haven't got time for you. So - if you care about me at all - go. JANE moves closer and closer to STEPHEN during this whole interchange - almost trapping STEPHEN, who is gallantly trying to resist being taken into her life.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I've got two years. I need to work.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I can't. His eyes widen. He can't believe his ears. He looks at he

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think--I've fallen in love with you. He can't speak now. This STUNS him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know. Strange. Inexplicable.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You've--you've leapt to--a false conclusion...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: My chances are probably - (shrugs) - well, some "integer of zero", but I think we can make a go of this. I want us to be together, for as long as we've got. And if that's not very long then - well, that's just how it is. It will have to do.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You don't realise what's coming. It'll affect everything. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 35

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She advances, and kisses him on the lips. He is still speechless. She stares into his eyes, with love --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Your glasses are always dirty. She takes them off, cleans them on her dress. His heart i exploding with joy and hope. She slips his GLASSES gently back on his nose.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. That's better. Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (powerfully moved) Yes. It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCIAMA is giving a TUTORIAL to FOUR UNDERGRADS -

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: ...the solutions to the Schrodinger equation must vanish at the boundary of the box, so we have... STEPHEN enters -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Time!

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Time. That's your subject? Any aspect of it, in particular?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Time. STEPHEN exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE is seated, watching FRANK as he ominously shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: You don't realize what lies ahead. His life is going to be very short. So. Be careful. Science is against you. And it's not going to be a fight, Jane. It's going to be a very heavy defeat. For all of us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 36

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I know--I know what you all think. That I don't look a terribly strong person. But I love him. And he loves me. We're going to fight this illness--all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER-8 FOOTAGE (MONTAGE) of - - STEPHEN and JANE are married. They pose for their WEDDI PHOTO, STEPHEN in black suit, tie, leaning on a SINGLE WALKING STICK; JANE in white, happy, as - - FLOWER PETALS drift down on them. Supered on BLUE sky: "TWO YEARS LATER"

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: SUPER-8 FOOTAGE (MONTAGE) of - - a small terrace house - a MINI parked outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER-8 FOOTAGE (MONTAGE) of - - a ONE YEAR-OLD BABY (ROBERT) is set into STEPHEN's arms is delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN SLIDES ON HIS BACK, down the STAIRS, dressed in a SUIT. He laughs at how ridiculous this is. JANE is there to meet him, to help him to his feet, to straighten his bow-tie. Both look nervous. Tenderly, she touches his face.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Ready. Good luck. Are you sure I can't drive you? STEPHEN smiles, gently shakes his head. She gives him his WALKING STICKS.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN walks with great difficulty up the hallway, using (for the first time) TWO WALKING STICKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN stops outside SCIAMA's office. Knocks with a stic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCIAMA and ROGER PENROSE and an American, KIP THORNE, fac STEPHEN.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Come in Stephen. STEPHEN makes his way slowly, laboriously, to stand in fr of the three examiners.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (his speech has worsened) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No thankyou.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: So. Chapters One--full of holes and lacks mathematical support. (to KIP THORNE) Professor Thorne?

dialogues.speaker: KIP THORNE
dialogues.text: Chapter Two--not really original-- uses a lot of Roger's ideas.

dialogues.speaker: PENROSE
dialogues.text: Well at least you run with them. Chapter Three? Too many unanswered questions.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: But Four? Silence. STEPHEN waits, as the PANEL turn the pages of hi thesis. STEPHEN grows WORRIED. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 38

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A black hole at the beginning of Time.

dialogues.speaker: KIP THORNE
dialogues.text: A spacetime singularity? SCIAMA and PENROSE and KIP THORNE look at each other. STE can't breath for the tension.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Brilliant. It's brilliant Stephen. So all that remains to be said is...well done. Or should I say, well done Doctor. And extraordinary theory.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Thankyou. STEPHEN sighs with RELIEF, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: So, what now?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Prove it. Prove...with a single equation, that Time has a beginning. Wouldn't that be nice Professor? One single elegant equation to explain everything?

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Yes. It would. It would indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAMPAGNE is OPENED and POURED. A celebrational dinner party, attended by JANE, BRIAN, EL REES, CARTER and two of their GIRLFRIENDS. JANE rises to a TOAST.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: To Doctor-

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: -Who? Over laughter -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: To Doctor Stephen Hawking.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 39

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRIAN holds forth on a funny story about him and Stephen, he uncorks a bottle of wine -

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: What's astonishing is that for Stephen and I, "work" was the worst four-letter word, the worst. (laughter) Stephen probably averaged, what was it?--an hour a day your entire university career? (laughter) Unbelievable levels of sloth! As the conversation turns into a HUBBUB of chatter, STEPH smiling, drops his FORK. JANE, in conversation now with o of the GIRLFRIENDS, picks up the fork without barely look at STEPHEN and put it back in front of him. STEPHEN watches everybody talking, eating, drinking, bein wonderfully, effortlessly dextrous. FRUSTRATED, ENVIOUS, saddened, STEPHEN watches closely then, before emotion br through, rises, grabs his TWO WALKING STICKS and starts t leave.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (concerned) Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Everyone watches him go with concern. It's a painful sigh see how hard it is for him to walk now. When he is gone only a few seconds, the guests stop their chatter when they hear a huge THUMP. Several men are abou rise to his aid when JANE signals for everyone to remain their place. Everyone understands and settles again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN tries to pull himself up the stairs by the spokes the balustrade. It takes him many seconds just to get up first stairs but we see his determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DINNER guests are now eating DESSERT, and talking quietly.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is only halfway up the STAIRS, using his last her energies. Finally, he STOPS, EXHAUSTED. Hearing something looks up - The TWO YEAR-OLD ROBERT has woken, and stands in his paja at the BABY-GATE at the top of the stairs, looking down a his father.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's okay Robert. For the first time - with his head resting on the step, a with his eyes turning back to look through the balusters the REFLECTION in a DINING ROOM mirror of the dinner part (his POV: tilted at 90 degrees) TEARS fall out of his eye PRIVATE MOMENT of great despair. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE and STEPHEN sip tea. Holding a cup is extremely difficult for him. A new tension exists between them. She watches him. Finally - she gets up, goes into the kitchen and then returns with... A WHEELCHAIR. She sets it before him. He stares at it. Is this his future? Is it an aid, or an enemy? She returns t the kitchen to wash some dishes while he stares at the chair...eventually rising, turning, poising above it, and then falling with a CRASH into it. JANE comes back to his side, realising the momentousness this moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: This--is--temporary.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE comes down the stairs, in her NIGHTIE, dressed for b carrying pillows. The MASTER BED now is erected in the little DINING ROOM, STEPHEN is propped up in it, smiling, waiting...(STEPHEN no longer manage the stair-climb.) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 41

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well, it's convenient for breakfast! She puts an extra pillow behind him, then they look into other's faces.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (playfully) Excuse me, did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I said--thankyou. They smile at each other. They kiss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEW-BORN BABY is put into STEPHEN's LAP for him to hold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NEW BABY'S CRIES carry (from UPSTAIRS) as JANE helps STEPHEN on with his PYJAMA TOP. She struggles to pull it over his head when the BABY's cries grow too urgent.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Go Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: One second. JANE runs out to go to the baby, runs up the stairs. STEPHEN struggles to pull on the PYJAMA himself.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INSIDE HIS PYJAMA. It’s dark. STEPHEN, helpless. His eyes are wide open, looking through the grain in the fabric at the OPEN FIRE, burning in the FIREPLACE.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Silence. He waits... The pin points of fire-light through the fabric, SLOWLY MORPH into STARS and a NIGHT SKY. This is what STEPHEN is visualizing. We see what he sees -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 42

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The LIFE OF THE UNIVERSE IN REVERSE...STARS being pulled back together, toward a single POINT, a SINGULARITY. As t SINGULARITY takes SHAPE, a DARK CIRCLE FORMS AROUND IT, rimmed by a GLOWING CIRCULAR HORIZON. FINALLY - A BLACK HOLE has FORMED. A POINT IN SPACE,

dialogues.speaker: GOBBLING STARS, ILLUMINATED ONLY AT ITS EDGES
dialogues.text: HORIZON) BY AN AMBIENT GLOW - A RING of LIGHT. The REVERIE ends as JANE eases the PYJAMA down over his head, returning STEPHEN back into the real world. He star at his wife, AWESTRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (breathless, stunned) I've got an idea. I've got an idea Jane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCIAMA runs, in great excitement, past KIP THORNE.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Kip! He's done it, Kip! He's -

dialogues.speaker: KIP THORNE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Stephen! He's changed everything! SCIAMA runs on, informing a mopping JANITOR -

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to JANITOR) Black Holes aren't black! And they explode! (running off) They explode!!... REACTION: KIP THORNE, confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is about to present his ideas to the conference. is SURROUNDED by his PEERS.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: All set? STEPHEN nods - nervous. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 43

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll do fine. AT A DISTANCE - at a TEA TABLE - excluded, and looking EXHAUSTED after a LONG NIGHT - JANE sits near TWO CLEANER WHITE, and overhears the female gossip about STEPHEN's condition.

dialogues.speaker: CHAR 1
dialogues.text: Look at him. It's awful, in't it? He's falling apart at the seams. JANE reacts, says nothing but bites her lips and frowns indignantly, as the CLEANERS walk away. JANE then approaches STEPHEN, nervously. But when he look at her, his EYES are BLAZING WITH LIGHT and passion - thi pulls her out of her SADNESS.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (lovingly) Good luck! He SMILES back at her, as the ENTRY DOORS to the HALL ope and REVEAL a PACKED EXPECTANT ROOM. It's daunting!

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Ready or not. SCIAMA PUSHES STEPHEN into the HALL, as - - JANE hurries to gather STEPHEN's NOTES, his WATER-BOTTL his BLANKET and her HANDBAG, only just slipping through t CLOSING DOORS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before his peers, STEPHEN finishes his address. SCIAMA si with JOHN TAYLOR in the front row. JANE sits toward the B

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (slurring slightly) .--allowing us to predict that some particles can in fact escape a black hole. Black holes aren't black at all, but glow with heat radiation. Stony, sceptical faces greet this outrageous idea. As STE continues his speech, ANGLE ON SCIAMA and TAYLOR.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: (aside, to TAYLOR) He's unifying Relativity--plus Quantum Mechanics and Thermodynamics. For the first time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 44

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TAYLOR
dialogues.text: (shakes head, to SCIAMA) Thermodynamics? Last used to describe the steam engine. During this exchange (0.S) STEPHEN has been saying:

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: In other words--the steady emission of heat energy causes black holes to slowly lose mass, they evaporate, eventually disappearing in a spectacular explosion. So... INTERCUT THIS LECTURE SCENE (as necessary) with the FOLLO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN and REES, CARTER and ELLIS discuss STEPHEN’s theory

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No,no! What he’s saying is--just as a hot body loses heat--right? -

dialogues.speaker: REES
dialogues.text: Second law of thermodynamics.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: - that a black hole - BRIAN dips a finger in the FROTH of REES's BEER and draws CIRCLE on the TABLETOP.

dialogues.speaker: REES
dialogues.text: - thanks -

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: - that if it is losin articles, then, then over time —

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: - it must eventually disappear. No applause at all as STEPHEN shuffles his notes. JANE lo nervous. SCIAMA also. The general reaction is guarded.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First a star vanishes into a black hole, but then the black hole must itself--vanish.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 45

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Gone! From nothing--into nothing.

dialogues.speaker: REES
dialogues.text: You owe me another beer.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: He's just told us that - (eating REES's CRISPS) - Time! Had a beginning! He shown us how -

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: (getting it) - the universe was born and how it will end.

dialogues.speaker: REES
dialogues.text: Bang. BRIAN crushes the precious bag of crisps.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Crunch! (entraptured) It's beautiful! It's racy! It's totally, totally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The stoney faces of the ACADEMIC AUDIENCE, all silent and unconvinced. STEPHEN on stage - looks at these blank faces. JANE and SCIAMA appear as nervous as JOHN TAYLOR, who ris then to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I'm afraid--this is complete nonsense. It's preposterous. TAYLOR drags a fellow colleague to his feet and WALKS OUT

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Was it something I said? SCIAMA rises to his feet, to defend STEPHEN -— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 46

dialogues.speaker: I-
dialogues.text: But then a BIG VOICE booms out - and stops TAYLOR and co their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: KHALATNIKOV
dialogues.text: STOP! Please. KHALATNIKOV makes his way to the STAGE, stopping beside STEPHEN. He addresses the audience gravely... KHALATNIKOV (CONT’D) My name--is Professor Khalatnikov, from Soviet Academy of Sciences. My field is evolution of the hot universe--the properties of microwave background radiation, and theory of the black holes. To be honest, I came here today expecting to hear a lot of nonsense. I go home disappointed. (pause, points) The little one here, has done it. (he smiles) He has done it! Applause finally begins, small, then grows large. KHALATNIKOV (CONT’D) HE!- HAS DONE IT! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ya Ya! He has done it! (Shakes Stephen's hand.) He has done it! REACTION JANE: Relief. REACTION STEPHEN: the famous grin appearing, as — STEPHEN is swamped by WELL-WISHERS. The AUDITORIUM emptie to the stage, where STEPHEN is SURROUNDED. ANGLE ON: JANE, alone suddenly in the AUDITORIUM, trying see STEPHEN, as he is borne out of the room on a tide of fame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is being pushed by BRIAN over the cobbled streets while REES, CARTER and ELLIS cavort around them. They are a PARTY/CELEBRATORY MOOD, singing as they go. GREAT FUN.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: At the base of a large flight of STEPS, the YOUNG PHYSICI all RACE EACH OTHER up the STEPS and disappear. BRIAN is alone with STEPHEN and the WHEELCHAIR. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 47

dialogues.speaker: BASTARDS
dialogues.text: BRIAN lifts STEPHEN out of his chair. He's heavy.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jeez!--uhhhh!--how the hell does Jane manage? He starts to carry STEPHEN up...up...up...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Big legs! Big legs Brian!

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: So, tell me, this Motor Neuron Disease, does it effect, y'know...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Everything. .? BRIAN indicates 'down there’.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Different system. Automatic.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: That's kinda wonderful, actually. And it explains a great deal about men. BRIAN and STEPHEN then disappears over the top of the STE After a few beats BRIAN reappears and runs down the steps reclaim the wheelchair. He picks it up and starts up the steps with it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, cradled in the giant arms of a seated MARBLE STATUE!!! (maybe Queen Victoria) - cradled like a baby, waiting for BRIAN to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHELVES are being restocked. The latest issue of "NAT MAGAZINE is set on the stand by a STOCKIST. The COVER rea “HAWKING RADIATION"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: STEPHEN. Waiting in his WHEELCHAIR on the front LAWN. About 8 YEARS have passed since we last saw him. Hi physical deterioration is marked. His body is thinner and powerless. His legs are bent and his face is slightly asymmetric. WIDE: Beside him is STACKED a mountain of FAMILY HOLIDAY LUGGAGE (umbrellas, beach balls, plastic cricket set, ten etc.) In the Background, the NEW WEST ROAD FLAT - a LARGE VICTO HOUSE. The sign in front reads "GONVILLE and CAIUS COLLEG On the LAWN the children (ROBERT, now 9 - and LUCY, now 5 PLAY with BEACH TOYS, until - - JANE (with a new haircut and fashion befitting the LATE 1970's) yells -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Get in the car! Get! In! The Car! Come on! Let's go see Gran and Grandad! The CHILDREN obey, and jump into the now OLD MINI parked the kerb, as - - JANE confronts the MOUNTAIN OF STUFF, including STEPHEN that must somehow be stowed. No way. LATER - back and forth JANE goes between LUGGAGE and MINI STEPHEN can only watch her load the stuff into the car an onto the ROOF-RACK. Finally - REVEAL the LOADED MINI - it looks ridiculously burdened! JANE takes a deep, exhausted, breath, then turns back for STEPHEN. He sits there in his wheelchair, looking at her. ROBERT and JANE together, with GREAT DIFFICULTY, get STEP into the front seat and shut the door. ROBERT struggles t COLLAPSE the WHEELCHAIR, until JANE comes and together th muscle it onto the ROOF-RACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK & ISOBEL HAWKING's tumble-down WELSH COTTAGE high a on a STEEP HILLSIDE, only reached by an ENORMOUS FLIGHT o STEPS. REACTION JANE: Exasperation! ISOBEL descends to greet them, followed by FRANK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 49

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Isn't it marvellous? We can rent it every year!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Yes. I see. But what about all the steps, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing. The climb is absolutely worth it. You get the luggage. FRANK backs STEPHEN (in his wheelchair) up the STEPS, one a time, while ISOBEL runs up ahead with the CHILDREN, lea JANE, alone, with ALL THE LUGGAGE. REACTION, JANE: Speechless in defeat, she sighs deeply. Finally, she slowly starts to unload the MINI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEA and CAKES al fresco. The CHILDREN play CHARADES. FRAN feeding STPHEN, but his attention is on...ROBERT, whose t it is...ROBERT acts being cold, that it's snowing...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: Oh--Rain?--Falling?--Rain Falling Down?--Shivering?--Uhhhrrrrr---

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Very cold... STEPHEN suffers an horrendous CHOKING FIT, which cannot b staunched. STEPHEN's parents, and little ROBERT watch in horror, as JANE tries in vain to subdue it, banging his b roughly, loosening his tie.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He needs to see a doctor. This keeps happening!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No doctors!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: Very well, no doctors. JANE, stressed, looks ready to break-down, and turns away hiding her frailty, a little angry also at the lack of support.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks slowly along path to the WOOD and sits down on STONE. Head in hands. She WEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE is driving them home.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I need help. I keep--I keep looking for a way-- to make this work--but I can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (forcefully, but with a slurred voice) We're fine--we're just a normal family.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (upset) WE'RE NOT A NORMAL FAMILY!!! We're not a normal family.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (turns to ROBERT) Robert--your mother's very angry at me. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (tearful) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A worried JANE cradles and sooths STEPHEN to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN in his old wheelchair is pushed from the KITCHEN JANE up to the doors to the LIVING ROOM. She has a surpri for him.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Ready? The doors then burst open and it's ROBERT and LUCY aboard ELECTRIC MOTORIZED WHEELCHAIR.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Surprise! Look Daddy Look! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 51

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STEPHEN stares as ROBERT makes the CHAIR turn by pulling pushing a toggle.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's an electric wheelchair. We can take it back--if you don't like it. STEPHEN stares at it, unsure at first...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While making dinner, JANE hears happy screams from the ot end of the house. She goes through to discover --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, in his motorized wheelchair, chasing ROBERT and from room to room at full speed! He looks extremely thril with the chair as he smashes into furniture. JANE, at the table, trying to work on her THESIS, tries t smile. STEPHEN motors away, chasing the squealing childre JANE WINCES as she hears - the sound (0.S.) of a SMASHING VASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN happily MOTORS at speed over the FOOT-BRIDGE, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is motoring along with SCIAMA. CAMBRIDGE DONS and STUDENTS step aside to make way.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: I don't get it. You've spent years assuming Black Holes exist--you believe Cygnus X-1 will turn out to be the first black hole we can actually observe==and yet you bet Kip Thorne that it isn't a black hole?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (slurring) Yes, a magazine subscription.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Why would you bet against yourself? (Pause) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 52

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A subscription to what? Nature magazine?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Pent-house. That way even if I'm wrong, I still win! SCIAMA laughs heartily as - - STEPHEN grins, at the same time SPYING - up ahead, TWO ATTRACTIVE UNDER-GRADUATE GIRLS about to enter the LIFT. STEPHEN hits the GAS! - and SPEEDS toward the LIFT...

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Penthouse? STEPHEN SPEEDS toward the LIFT, whose DOORS ARE READY TO CLOSE. SCIAMA winces in expectation of a horrible accident. WIDE: it looks suicidal but the chair just flies through GAP in the last split second before the DOORS CLOSE - the doors shaving the wheels, with a small spark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, in there with the TWO UNDERGRADUATE GIRLS, SMILE them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE picks up pieces of a BROKEN POTTED PLANT, dirt spill over the carpet, then violently VACUUMES as BERYL comes i with a tea-tray.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Jane--Jane? Jane? Jane! STOP! JANE keeps VACUUMING. BERYL pulls the PLUG on the VACUUM CLEANER. JANE stares at her Mum.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit down. Sit. BERYL pours TEA for the exhausted JANE. JANE sits.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now--I'd like to make a suggestion-- it might sound unusual--but I've seen it work wonders. I think--you should consider - (beat) - joining the church choir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 53

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: REACTION JANE: Momentarily SPEECHLESS -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Mum--I think that is possibly the most English thing anyone has ever said.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Maybe so.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I used to love singing.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: You're very good at it.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Go. (pause) It's one hour a week. They sip tea in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks in - and up the AISLE - as we hear CHORAL MUSI JANE takes a pew, and then her eyes widen slightly as she recognizes the CHOIR MASTER. It's the BEARDED MAN from th supermarket car-park. She studies him, as he gently instructs and then conducts the CHOIR.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: After the rehearsal, the CHOIR file past JANE. JONATHAN recognizes her at once.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, hello.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Are you here to sing?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I um--I just came to--

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Soprano? Soprano.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 54

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Mezzo?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (pointing downwards) Alto.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well--Just what we need. (to last departing chorister) "Bye, Kate. (to JANE) Where have you been hiding?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Good question.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well, you're here now. And just in time.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Am I?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes. So tell me. (squints, thinking) Chopin! Yes? Your repertoire.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't call it a repertoire. Brahms--I know a little-

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Brahms! Wonderful. Perfect. We - JONATHAN gets an idea, he moves then stops... JONATHAN (CONT’D) Okay. Which...?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, I have sung--"Immer leiser."

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Ah! "My sleep grows evermore peaceful." Come on. Follow me. Come on. Let me hear you. Come on. He sets off up to the front of the church. She turns, smiling, as he WAVES for her to follow him. She follows.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the front of the church she sees that he is already sitting at the piano. Without sheet music he begins to pl "Immer leiser wird mein Schlummer"...

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (over the music) Jonathan. Jonathan Hellyer Jones. She gingerly approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Jane. Jane Hawking.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: In C-sharp minor? The introduction, so lovely. From the top?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: "Living on the edge." (smiles) Ready? (beat) If you're not in the mood we could absolutely forget -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No, no. No, no. Just let me remember the lyrics. In English.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Okay? (beat) Two, three...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (sings) My sleep grows ever quieter only my grief, like a veil, lies trembling over me. I often hear you in my dreams calling outside my door...(etc)  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE and JONATHAN emerge from the church - JONATHAN locks doors.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Actually, no, I go for the Gospel of St. Mark.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: None of that wishy-washy do-gooder stuff--Matthew, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Exactly. With Mark you roll up your sleeves and get stuck in. No standing on the sidelines. They shake hands. JANE stares into his face - realizing s has found a friend.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well I should be going.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well met. Oh, and if your daughter would like those piano lessons.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Absolutely. My husband loves music too.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I could teach him as well.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Well, that's a long story. 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN motors down the street, fast, and swings up the ramp in front of the door. He BANGS into the front door. Then waits. He hears PIANO music - a lesson in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As STEPHEN and JANE watch - JONATHAN gives ROBERT (11) a piano lesson. JANE smiles at STEPHEN, who remains cautious.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONATHAN is eating dinner with JANE and STEPHEN. JANE fee STEPHEN a forkful of food. STEPHEN chews slowly. STEPHEN sneaks glances at JONATHAN. JONATHAN shoots a SMILE at JANE. She smiles back in retur STEPHEN catches sight of both these smiles, and sees the GROWING INTIMACY.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Water. She exits. JONATHAN smiles at STEPHEN who is staring back him.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (to STEPHEN) So - Stephen. Er - Jane tells me... JONATHAN picks up STEPHEN's fork, spears a cube of steak. JONATHAN (CONT’D) .+-you have a beautiful theorem that proves that... JONATHAN offers up the steak, but STEPHEN's glare makes h aware this isn't welcome. He lowers the fork again. JONATHAN (CONT’D) ...that--that the universe had a beginning? JANE returns with the a JUG OF WATER and GLASSES on a TRA

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (testily, his slurring not easily understood) That was my - PhD thesis. JONATHAN looks to JANE for a translation.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Your...?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: PhD thesis.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: My new project - disproves it.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Disproves it? Really? (as JANE nods) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 58

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You no longer believe in the Creation?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What one believes - - is irrelevant--in physics.

dialogues.speaker: JANE JONATHAN
dialogues.text: -..is irrelevant -..is irrelevant

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: ...in physics. JONATHAN looks to JANE, hoping he has not caused offence.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, is that so?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (annoyance showing) Stephen's done a U-turn. The big new idea is that the universe has no boundaries at all. No boundaries, no beginning. No beginning -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: - no God? Really? (to STEPHEN) Fascinating. Because I'd understood you'd proven the need for a Creator. My mistake.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No. Mine.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (understanding this) Yours. Your mistake? JONATHAN is surprised by this sharp reply. (He also sees that this matter is a CAUSE OF DIVISION between JANE and

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stephen is looking for a single law that governs all the forces in the universe. So God must die.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Why must God die? I don't see. STEPHEN doesn't react, so JANE spears a PEA on her FORK, then picks up a SECOND FORK and spears a LARGE BOILED POTATO with the other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 59

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The two great pillars of physics are - (the PEA) - Quantum Theory, the laws that govern the very small--electrons, particles so on--and General Relativity...

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes - Einstein.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: ..-Einstein's theory. (the POTATO) Which governs the very large, planets and such--but Quantum - (raises the PEA) and - (raises the POTATO) Relativity...

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: They 're--different?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They don't remotely play by the same rules. Peas are chaotic, and don't behave predictably at all - With her 'pea' fork she stirs some more peas on her plate creates 'chaos'.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Unlike--potatoes -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Which you can set your watch by.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Very good. Even STEPHEN has begun to begrudgingly enjoy this, even a he starts COUGHING. JANE gets up and goes to pat STEPHEN's back over the following:

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: If the world were all potatoes, easy--you could trace a precise beginning, as Stephen once did, a moment of Creation. Hallelujah, God lives. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 60 (3)

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if you want to incorporate peas into the menu, which Stephen now wants to do, then it all goes

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Tits up. JONATHAN looks to JANE for translation again -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Tits up. Haywire. Becomes a Godless mess.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, dear.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Einstein hated peas, Quantum Theory. "God doesn't play dice with the universe", he said.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Seems he not only plays dice -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Seems he not only plays dice -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: - he throws them - where we can't find them. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - he throws them -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: - where we can't find them. How inconvenient!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stephen's swapped his telescope (un-spears the spud) - for a microscope. (eats the pea) Order for chaos--hoping to find a law to cover both. impressed, looks at STEPHEN.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Looking for "the world in a grain of sand."

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: God is back on the endangered species list. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING (4)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I expect he'll cope.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: But physics--is back in business.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Physics is back in business. Stephen thinks it a fair exchange.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (to JANE) It's the final--challenge. We'll know everything.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: The final challenge?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (to JONATHAN, ignoring

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: More wine? JONATHAN declines, troubled by the tension between the couple.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (resigned) We'll know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a STARRY sky - JONATHAN helps STEPHEN sip his coffe STEPHEN accepts this now.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It was leukaemia. Coming up on a year ago. She fought it, I nursed her, but in the end... Music is my salvation. Teaching and playing. I've struggled with loneliness, of course. Tyranny of the empty room, all that. Music is a consolation, although my career... Well, I'm not very ambitious. (smiles) Is that a sin?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Wrong guy to ask. 61  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONATHAN puts on his JACKET to go - JANE and STEPHEN see off.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. It was wonderful. (starts to go, then stops) And if--if there was anything I can do. To be of service. To you, your family. I have no children, no commitments. If I could help you, I believe I would find a purpose that would alleviate my own situation. It would be a privilege. STEPHEN looks to JANE for her reaction. JANE senses EMOTIONAL DANGER and, frightened, merely smiles. JONATHAN (CONT’D) Night then. He exits. JANE shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE puts PILLOWS behind STEPHEN, who now sleeps almost upright in bed. She then takes off her BATHROBE and gets into bed herself.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I understand you need more help. And if there is - someone - who is prepared to offer it - I won't object, as long - as long as you continue to love me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Of course. For infinity. Beside him in bed, she kisses his cheek and then lays her head on his frail chest. MUSIC UP: BACH PRELUDE, as played by JONATHAN on PIANO, o

dialogues.text: A) (MOVED TO: POSITION "G" in MONTAGE) Al) The CAM RIVER. A PUNT on a SUNNY DAY drifts under the BRIDGE OF SIGHS - in the front of the PUNT, JANE cradles STEPHEN and ROBERT and LUCY. JANE smiles at - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 63

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: - JONATHAN, who is POLING them. He smiles back at her. B) HAWKING FRONT ROOM. JONATHAN plays the BACH PRELUDE divinely on JANE's PIANO, as - JANE, BESIDE HIM on the pi stool, turns the pages. STEPHEN watches without jealousy with enjoyment. C) HAWKING BATHROOM. JONATHAN takes STEPHEN to the TOILET D) When JONATHAN and JANE pass each other in the KITCHEN, and JONATHAN quite naturally takes her hand. JANE, surprised, looks at him. He SMILES at her. Their FIRST

dialogues.speaker: TOUCH
dialogues.text: We can see that the temptation to act further on their feelings is now HUGE for both of them, but they do nothin JANE forces herself to break away, hurries into the next room to be with STEPHEN, the kids and a train set. JONATH is left to deal with his feelings. He sighs, sublimates them, then returns to his domestics. E) BRANCASTER BEACH. SUPER-8 FOOTAGE of their day at the beach... STE helplessly watches from his wheelchair as JONATHAN engage some playful rough and tumble with ROBERT and LUCY, kicki FOOTBALL back and forth. JANE watches on. JONATHAN cradles STEPHEN as they sit there and look out t sea, both men carefree and happy, STEPHEN accepting of JONATHAN's care now. They appear as FRIENDS now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHOIR sings a beautiful CAROL. The CAMERA finds JANE singing nervously - the only SINGER NOT LOOKING at JONATH her eyes are glued on her hymn sheet. In DENIAL.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: After the Rehearsal, the CHOIR leaves. JANE and JONATHAN clear up the hymn sheets. She passes her pile to him. He his hand on hers. She withdraws her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I have to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Is anything the matter? She looks at him for the first time that evening -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm um--I'm pregnant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 64

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh. (wounded) I see. I presumed--stupid really-- that you and Stephen... (courageously) Well, then... (awkwardly) Congratulations are in order.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Does it make a difference?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (nobly) Of course not. He takes her by the arm, and leads her out of the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is gathered for the CHRISTENING PARTY - STEPHEN, JANE, their PARENTS, ROBERT, LUCY. BRIAN takes PHOTOS of EVERYONE. JANE places the new BABY (TIMOTHY) into STEPHEN's LAP (an carefully holds TIM there as STEPHEN can no longer hold a baby) as - - JONATHAN takes a PHOTO of the MOMENT. ANGLE ON: FRANK HAWKING, scowling at JONATHAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. As the party continues, FRANK sits with STEPHEN. F glances at JONATHAN, who brings drinks for the ladies. He turns to his son.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: I've always supported you in your choice not to have home help, but now, you need a permanent solution. This--this current 'situation' can't go on. You need a proper live- in nurse immediately.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: We have help.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: You know what I'm talking about. STEPHEN glances at JONATHAN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 65

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (slurred speech) Can't afford--live-in nurse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: You can't afford to-- (stops himself) There must be a way. You need to find a way. For your family's sake. You're world famous -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: For black holes--not rock concerts.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK HAWKING
dialogues.text: I believe it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ISOBEL HAWKING follows JANE into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: You know very well what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: No. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: We do have a right to know. We have a right to know, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Know what?!

dialogues.speaker: ISOBEL
dialogues.text: Whose child Timothy is. Stephen's, or Jonathan's? JANE, turning, wheeling on ISOBEL, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: That's what you think of me? ANGLE ON JONATHAN, appearing at the door, unseen by the WOMEN. He overhears the following.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is no way that Timothy could have any other father than Stephen. None. And for the record--I will never leave Stephen. JANE turns - sees that JONATHAN is standing in the DOORWA JONATHAN exits...  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE chases JONATHAN - stops him.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I need to go. I can't...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Please don't go.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Everyone's talking. It's -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So. What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well, there are other things too. I - I - just - (beat) I have feelings for you.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I have feelings for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN JANE
dialogues.text: It's - it's difficult for me! I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN JANE
dialogues.text: You have no - It's so wonderful, for me, for the children.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN JANE
dialogues.text: I have to go. I don't think I Please, please - can —

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Perhaps the right thing is for me to just--step back. He walks off. REACTION JANE: Distressed. ANGLE ON: STEPHEN, at the WINDOW, watching this - CONCERN

dialogues.text: JANE does her daily NURSE chores, among these applying ha lotion quickly to STEPHEN's hands - she does this ROUTINELY. (This will contrast, later, with how Elaine applies the hand lotion.)

dialogues.text: I've just been invited - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING

dialogues.text: Invited? Where?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Geneva.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Geneva?

dialogues.text: Students can accompany me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: What students?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I know how much you hate -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: You know how much I hate -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: - to fly. JANE nods, sensing they are at a crossroads. She looks away, on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: To fly. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I was thinking - that you and the children -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - Me and the children--go on?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: could bring the car -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - bring the car -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: - meet me in Bayreuth -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Bayreuth? How can I manage that? On my own?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Bring Jonathan. JANE looks up at him. Her thoughts racing. 67 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 68

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BOTH understand the significance of this. She looks into eyes to establish if he is sure. The look he gives her confirms this.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I doubt he would be willing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN motors up the CHURCH AISLE with TWO BOTTLES OF BE in a PAPER BAG at his side going "CLINK,CLINK,CLINK". JONATHAN clearing up after a CHOIR PRACTICE turns - stare STEPHEN.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: FRONT ROW of the PEWS. JONATHAN and STEPHEN, side-by-side stare at the ALTAR. JONATHAN spots the BEER BOTTLES in STEPHEN's LAP.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Is--this okay?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well--I won't tell if you don't. JONATHAN opens the TWO BEER BOTTLES, tucks his handkerchi under STEPHEN's chin, and then tips the beer into STEPHEN mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHON
dialogues.text: Not too much--bearing in mind you have to drive. STEPHEN grins. The two men stare at the ALTAR, aware of the significance this moment. STEPHEN sneaks a glance at JONATHAN. And the

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Jane--needs--help. JONATHAN sighs deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG MALE STUDENT CARER, loads the last of STEPHEN's LUGGAGE into a TAXI. STEPHEN is already in the back of th TAXI with SARAH, a carer. JANE supervises, worried.
