dialogues.text: And please please remember, 5 milligrams of Riluzole before and after the flight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 69

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She then goes to STEPHEN's open window.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (jaunty) See you - in Bayreuth.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Travel safely. She kisses his cheek. The MALE STUDENT and SARAH get in t cab, which DRIVES OFF. JANE smiles and waves till the cab gone. She slowly turns and re-enters her home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE, the two youngest CHILDREN and JONATHAN play hide-an seek in the college garden.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Forty-nine...Fifty. Coming ready or not! JANE searches for the CHILDREN...she instead sees - throu the undergrowth - MEN's SHOES! She rises. It's JONATHAN standing there. They look into e other’s eyes. What will they do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JONATHAN drives, ROBERT is in the PASSENGER SEAT. JANE is in the BACK SEAT with LUCY - (TIMOTHY is absent). JANE an JONATHAN make eye-contact via the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the show starts, STEPHEN in his WHEELCHAIR in the AISLE, happy, as we hear the ORCHESTRA tuning. He is flan by SARAH and the MALE STUDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They erect TWO TENTS. Jane and the kids one, Jonathan the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER - JANE creeps out of the tent in which LUCY and TIM sleeping. There is a third sleeping bag in there - her ow JANE then goes to the adjoining tent - JONATHAN's. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 70

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JANE PAUSES for a moment, bites her lip, breathless, unab to make herself enter the TENT. Just then, JONATHAN unzips his tent and emerges. They LOCK EYES on each other - an incredibly charged attraction between them. He reaches for her HAND. She is shaking. TOGETHER they go into JONATHAN's tent. END ON: t zip being closed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN coughs a few times as he listens to the PRELUDE o the RING CYCLE. HIS POV of: The DARKENED STAGE, a black void, but for a BURNING RING at its centre. STEPHEN begins to cough a little harder, then a little harder. The CARER, SARAH, at his side, finally takes note holds a WHITE HANDKERCHIEF up to his MOUTH. He SUDDENLY COUGHS BLOOD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN's POV of the THEATRE CEILING as he is stretchered of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE stands in a phonebox, then slams down the PHONE and rushes back to the CAMPSITE in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VOLVO drives through the night. Takes an exit marked "GENEVA".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN lies quiet and still, his eyes closed. JANE looks down on him. She has GUILTY tears in her eyes. The SWISS DOCTOR enters, speaks with JANE...Tout en Francais...with ENGLISH SUBTLTLES.

dialogues.speaker: SWISS DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (in FRENCH) He has pneumonia. He is on a life- support machine. I am not certain how long he will live. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 71

dialogues.speaker: SWISS DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to know whether my staff should disconnect the ventilator? JANE switches to ENGLISH -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SWISS DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (in ENGLISH) If we try to bring him round from the anaesthetic it is not sure he will survive resuscitation.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Stephen must live! You have to bring him round from the anaesthetic!

dialogues.speaker: SWISS DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is what you want? The only way of weaning him off the ventilator would be to give him a tracheotomy, a hole in the neck, by-passing the throat. He will never speak again. JANE stares at him - deeply upset but finally manages to say -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: There's no question. Stephen must live. I will see he gets everything he needs. I will have him transferred back to Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: SWISS DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He may not survive the journey. JANE looks pale and weaker than we have ever seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tarmac, the two HAWKING children are led toward a FLIGHT (in the far distance) by an AIR-HOSTESS. Meanwhile, A small AIR-RESCUE PLANE nearby awaits JANE an STEPHEN. STEPHEN is just then being loaded on board. JANE turns and faces JONATHAN. A private moment. Her LOOK OF SADNESS speaks volumes. He NODS - he KNOWS.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I'll step back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 72

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She NODS, SADLY. Her eyes start to well up. His too. It's break-up. Turning to look back to the plane...

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Drive--safely, yes? Did you get everything in the car? His chair, equipment... JONATHAN nods. She KISSES him on the cheek and he presses his cheek agai hers. They both hold onto each other for a moment, knowin it's their final embrace, and then she hurries, tearfully toward the WAITING PLANE, leaving him standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE, is gowned for theatre. With an ENGLISH DOCTOR she watches the OP through a window.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH DOCTOR
dialogues.text: It'll take a miracle. ANGLE ON: JANE's POV - of the surgeon picking up a MARKER PEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A SURGEON prepares to perform a TRACHEOTOMY on STEPHEN marking the spot on his neck with the MARKER PEN, and the picks up the SCALPEL...about to make the INCISION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REACTION JANE: as - she WINCES, then GASPS in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN opens his eyes, looks around him. He is alone. He opens his mouth to speak. We hear only a slow exhale of air, through the off-screen tracheotomy hole. He PANICS, and has to be soothed by a NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER. STEPHEN is turned on his side, his back to camera. JANE enters. APPROACHES. ANGLE ON: Her POV of STEPHEN as she approaches, revealing the side of his face, and then finally, his neck with the TRACHEOTOMY HOLE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 73

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She can't help it. Her hand JUMPS UP to cover her mouth a she gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recuperating in his chair in the sun, staring out of the window at - a BIRD PERCHED which alights a branch. STEPHEN has never looked more depressed. Or alone. There plastic FLANGE over the TRACHEOTOMY HOLE. ANGLE ON the FINGERS of his right hand, resting on the ar of the wheelchair. These, at least, can still move.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stephen? JANE moves into STEPHEN's limited POV - holding a CLEAR PLASTIC SCREEN - an E-TRAN "SPELLING" BOARD, on which 6 groups of characters are arranged.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a Spelling Board. First, you tell me what letter you want by blinking when I say the colour of the group that contains that letter. Once I know the group, you can choose the character inside that group by blinking again when I go through the colours of each letter in that group. Apparently. Okay? Let's just try. STEPHEN says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...Green, Yellow, Blue, White, Black, Red. (silence) Blink to choose the group that contains the letter you want? Green? Yellow? Blue? White? Black? Red? As JANE's eyes fill with TEARS...STEPHEN just keeps looki at her...then TRIES TO SPEAK. His mouth moves...but nothi nothing ever again! - will ever come out! It's a heart-breaking moment-- for both of them--and when TEARS appear in his eyes, she can't stop her own TEARS fr falling.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN gloomily reads a newspaper with the help of a REA FRAME, when — JANE enters.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: She's here. Okay. Promise not to eat her alive... Enter: ELAINE MASON. She is attractive. Exit: JANE, touching ELAINE supportively on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: So then - Professor. How are you? My name is Elaine. I'm going to be your nurse, would you like that? No? Well- we'll work it out. He stares at her, as - - ELAINE goes and gets a CHAIR, taking an interest in her until - - ELAINE turns and catches him look at her. Swiftly, STEPHEN turns his eyes back to the NEWSPAPER. EL looks at him a moment longer, surprises to see that STEPH is not unlike any other man in this regard. A faint smile appears. She sits in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE holds the E-TRAN BOARD and writes down a letter, t looks up at STEPHEN - sees through the clear perspex immediately what group he is looking at. She doesn't have call out the colours - knows them. (See her POV of him through the board so we establish the eye-line principle. She is BRILLIANT at this. STEPHEN's eyes FLICK from GROUP to GROUP, no BLINKING goi on.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Red group--Yellow letter. T. Green group--Black letter. E. Green-- Green. A....T.E.A. Tea. (smiles) You're good. You want tea. What type of tea? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 75

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look at each other. And then she has an IDEA. She PU DOWN THE BOARD. They look at each other...

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've memorised the board. Of course you have. What kind of tea? Blink when I say the group that has the letter you want. Green, Yellow, Blue, White, Black, Red... (beat) I haven't got all day. Green- (He BLINKS) Green group. And the letter in that group? You know their colours, I know you do. Green, Yellow - He BLINKS. She has MEMORISED the BOARD too -

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yellow? Green,yellow--that's B. A breakthrough. They are both EXPERT.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A tea beginning with B? Builder's tea! Right? He GRINS. She SMILES. She goes to get him some TEA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE, smiling, enters hall (from the LIVING ROOM) and b into JANE, who has just arrived home with GROCERIES. They stop in front of each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) I think he’s the most brilliant man I’ve ever met. You’re very lucky.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You must worship the ground beneath his -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - wheels. JANE can't fail to see how enthralled ELAINE is.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: And he’s the perfect patient. Looking after him is so much easier than other patients I've had. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 76

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And sooo funny, oh my God. When you read about him people don't tell you -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) You only do two shifts a week, Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN sits in the armchair, propped up by cushions, whi TECHNICIAN bolts the NEW COMPUTER SCREEN onto STEPHEN's WHEELCHAIR. JANE watches.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Almost there!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: How does it work?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: A guy called Walt Woltosz invented the software. Uses a very simple interface that scans through the alphabet and allows each letter to be selected one by one. Using this technique, the Professor can expect to write at about four words per minute. ELAINE enters -—

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (After initial dismay) Better than one a minute.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: What I've done is--use components from a telephone answering system actually-- to convert the written text into synthesized speech. The voice sounds a bit robotic, but... (it's ready) Okay. Shall we give it a try?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: JANE and ELAINE hoist STEPHEN into the new chair.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we go. (grandly) Welcome to the future! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 77

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The TECHNICIAN sets a pressure-sensitive 'clicker' in STEPHEN's hand. The SCREEN suddenly floods with COMPUTER CODE. REFLECTED in the glass is the WIDE-EYED FACE OF STEPHEN. JANE and ELAINE sit on the couch together watching - The TECHNICIAN demonstrates - builds a sentence for STEPHEN, selecting one LETTER at a time. STEPHEN is all concentration, observing how it is done.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All set. Then you just click "PLAY', like this - STEPHEN looks back at the screen, then CLICKS ONCE. The COMPUTER comes to life and says STEPHEN's first words in months.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (electronic voice, strong American accent) My--name--1s--Stee--ven--Hawking. STEPHEN stares at JANE - incredulous. JANE stares back at STEPHEN - horrified.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: It's American! Oh, my Goodness. (to TECHNICIAN) Are there any other voices?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: That's all they have at the moment. Is that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I think it's great! STEPHEN looks bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet moment, STEPHEN sits alone, trying out the new device. His face shows SADNESS, BLEAKNESS. His eyes move to the COMPUTER SCREEN. His fingers CLICK-CLICK-CLICK on monitor. And finally we hear - his sadly moving homage (t "2001: A Space Odyssey").

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Daisy. Daisy. (beat) Give Me Your Answer Do. Finally - he SMILES. He has cheered himself up.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN motors through the house, as we hear -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Frankly my dear, I don't give a damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the OPEN DOORS into the LIVING ROOM we hear TIMOT squealing with joyous delight, then see him run out - As TIM passes out of shot we hear then see STEPHEN slowly motor out of the LIVING ROOM, chasing him, with - - a LARGE BROWN PAPER GROCERY BAG OVER HIS HEAD (TWO EYE- HOLES cut in it, a SMILE DRAWN over the mouth) as STEPHEN voice-synthesizer loudly proclaims the DALEK war-cry from DOCTOR WHO as STEPHEN chases his son around:

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Ex-terminate..! Ex-terminate..! Ex-terminate..!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE approaches as STEPHEN writes, CLICK,CLICK,CLICK. His eyes turn to her as she hears:

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I will write. A Book.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: At four words a minute? About what? STEPHEN clicks. She moves to look at his SCREEN. TIGHT ON SCREEN as he selects: T IM E.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Time... She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) The HANDS ON A CLOCK turn very quickly, TIME running f B) STEPHEN motors down the cloisters of his college. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 79

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is the nature of Time? C) His PALSIED RIGHT HAND clicks the CLICKER, as he works home at night.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will it ever come to an end? D) A PRINTER prints out the text we hear in V/O -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can we go back in time? E) He works in office at DAMPTP.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some day these answers may seem as obvious to us as the earth orbiting the sun, or perhaps as ridiculous as a tower of tortoises. He SMILES. F) He motors by the college at sunset.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Only Time, whatever that may be, will tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE opens his LETTERS, and looks at him. STEPHEN works on his book - it's slow laborious work. CLI CLICK, CLICk... ELAINE picks up, from the mail, a SEALED COPY of PENTHOUS MAGAZINE (Addressed to: "KIP THORNE c/- PROF.S.HAWKING")

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Professor? STEPHEN looks over at her - sees the MAGAZINE, that ELAIN smiling, is starting to UNWRAP. He urgently types a voice message - click, click, click - but he isn't fast enough she has opened it. Too late he clicks "PLAY"

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It is for a friend.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: ‘Course it is. That's what they all say. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 80

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She surprises him by crossing the room and opening the PA of the MAGAZINE for him.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't have to be embarrassed around me, Professor. I know what men are like. SURPRISED, STEPHEN finds himself with the PENTHOUSE open before him. He looks at the MAGAZINE, then at ELAINE, the the MAGAZINE. Just then - office DOOR OPENS. Enter, SCIAMA. He stops wh he sees the MAGAZINE.

dialogues.speaker: SCIAMA
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry. He exits, blushing. STEPHEN grins. ELAINE bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Next one? He SMILES at her - falling in love with her. She detects this, happily.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, alone, continues to write, one painstaking word a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE, exhausted, rubbing her eyes as she PROOF-READS STEPHEN's text, like the old days. She pauses, looks up, the next room, at — - ELAINE laughing at something the grinning STEPHEN has s JANE resumes work on STEPHEN's BOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN still working - CLICK, CLICK, CLICK...

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: He ponders this. Then has an idea. CLICK, CLICK, CLICK. H inserts "BRIEF" into the title. He stares at the screen.  THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE PAGE is spat out of PRINTER: "A BRIEF HISTORY OF

dialogues.speaker: TIME."
dialogues.text: While reading the LAST PAGE manuscript for his book, JANE stops and is stunned by something she reads. She rises, a rushes - with the LAST PAGE - into the next room where -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A PHOTO of STEPHEN and a MARILYN MONROE LOOK-A- LIKE, hangs on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So I said - I have long been looking for a model of the universe. I finally found her. Beside the PHOTO, ELAINE finishes SHAVING STEPHEN - then steps away to pick up some HAND LOTION. She inadvertently show him some LEG. STEPHEN notices. ELAINE laughs, and starts to massage LOTION, almost lovingly, into his HAND. JANE announce her presence.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Elaine? Can we - ? ELAINE comes over to JANE, still chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I spoke with Stephen alone for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: We're not quite finished--can you come back in ten minutes? REACTION JANE: Slightly ruffled feathers. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE walks in, holding a page from the MANUSCRIPT. STEPHE is 'typing' a message.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (reads ) “Who are we? Why are we here? If we ever learn this, it would be the ultimate triumph of human reason, for then we would know the mind of God." (to him) 'GOD'? Do you really mean this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 82

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STEPHEN types his reply.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yes. (types) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: So you're acknowledging him? But as he continues to CLICK, feverishly, she excitedly exits, before he can add another word. He tries to genera the next word before she disappears but he is alone again by the time his computer belatedly spits out -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: However -— He sags, frustrated that he was not fast enough to set he straight - but then she comes back in -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Did you just say something? STEPHEN decides not to respond.

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're actually going to let me have this moment. STEPHEN click-click-clicks, then -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You - are - welcome. She smiles. She kisses him on the cheek, and then as she starts to leave - - on his SCREEN - STEPHEN selects the message he was writing earlier...clicks "PLAY." We hear -

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: E-laine has offered to travel with me to A-merica. She will look after me.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (immensely hurt) Will she?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Don't worry. He clicks "STOP". She nods, sadly. He smiles, sweetly. Both accept what is happening, but sadly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 83

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: America? (beat) You always used to tell me when an invitation came in.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (the old grin) A-nother a-ward. What can you do? JANE smiles, warmly. STEPHEN writes.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything will be okay. She tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How many years? STEPHEN writes. She waits. His eyes flick between his screen and her.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: They said - two. We've had so many. The look in his eyes is his eloquent reply. Emotion overc JANE. Can this really be how it ends? It's so sad and bizarre and they both realise it in this moment. She tries to hide her tears by walking away from him and turning her back, hiding her face. STEPHEN watches her, as aware of the enormous significanc this moment as she - then slowly - slowly - motors toward her. He stops just behind her, then nudges her leg, ever gently, with his own lifeless foot, the way a pony will n its familiar rider. He clicks "PLAY"

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Be. Happy. She turns back, CROUCHES, comes down to his level - right front of him, eye to eye -

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I have loved you. (beat) I did my best. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 84

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As TEARS form in his own eyes, he BLINKS ONCE at her - th only form of communication that feels right in that momen and she understands all that it means. She smiles through her tears as she SMOOTHS HIS HAIR. Finally - words are not needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MOVERS pack STEPHEN's PRIZES and MEDALS, lifting them from the SIDEBOARD, as - JANE watches, hiding her emotion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window is dominated by a single display for STEPHEN’s book - A Brief History Of Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The SUNDAY TIMES NEWSPAPER. The BEST-SELLER LIS ECU on: A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, at NUMBER 1. Weeks: 8 WIDE. JANE and her MOTHER, BERYL, at the dining table, th PAPER spread out before them.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Remarkable. How is he?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: He wants to marry her.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Don't blame yourself. We're proud of you. JANE is touched.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I'm trying hard not to think of this as a failure.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: But it wasn't a failure.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: But it feels like it! It feels like it, Mum. (beat) Was it inevitable? BERYL doesn't know what to say. Yes it was. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THEORY of EVERYTHING 85

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Perhaps too many people were drawn in? (silence) What will Stephen do next?

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) He's gone back to looking for his Theory Of Everything, his single equation. Well, it’1l have to explain human relationships too. BERYL ponders this:

dialogues.speaker: JANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s going to have to be a wonderful piece of mathematics. (ponders) All the accidents...

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: All the unexpected forces... attractions... JANE looks at her mother quickly - "attractions"?

dialogues.speaker: BERYL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wistful, dreamy) A attracts B --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: And vice versa.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Then add Time - Adversity -

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Yes. Adversity over time --

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: - until the situation becomes unstable, heats up.

dialogues.speaker: BERYL
dialogues.text: Bang!

dialogues.speaker: JANE
